Hostilities and the presence of landmines hinder repairs and maintenance work, exacerbating WASH needs in NGCAs in particular.? Older people are more likely to remain in these areas and are therefore disproportionally affected. ? The worsening socioeconomic situation and restrictions on movement have affected access to food and basic services such as education and health, limited livelihood opportunities, and triggered the displacement of 1.5 million people.?

INFORM measures Ukraine's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 5.2/10. Hazard exposure rating is also very high at 7/10.? 

ACCESS SITUATION

People living in the demilitarised area, which covers 15km on either side of the contact line, lack continuous access to assistance.? Access to NGCAs in particular is decreasing as bureaucratic obstacles are limiting the operations of humanitarian partners and restricting humanitarian access.?  At the same time the Ukraine is one of the countries with the highest number of casualties reported from antivehicle mines and landmines, improvised mines and ERWs (429 in 2017). Demining efforts are slow as some affected areas are not under government control.?
UKR.latest_developments_past: 18/01: Civilian casualties declined by more than 50%  in 2018 in comparison to 2017. Ceasefire violations decreased until mid-January following a re-commitment to the ceasefire in late December.?

VEN.main:
Due to lack of data available, the scale and scope of humanitarian needs in Venezuela cannot be accurately assessed following ACAPS methodology. However, the ongoing economic crisis has led to a deterioration of the overall humanitarian situation in the country. For this reason, ACAPS is monitoring closely the situation in Venezuela and will on ad hoc basis publish reports. Venezuela will remain categorized as “no severity”. 

See our special reports on Venezuela
VEN.latest_developments_upcoming: 21/01: The number of Venezuelans fleeing their country is expected to reach 5.3 million by the end of 2019. The economic situation will likely continue to deteriorate, with the inflation rate predicted to reach 10,000,000% in 2019, a significant increase from the 1,700,000% at the end of 2018 ?.

YEM.main:
Yemen is facing a severe humanitarian crisis due to longstanding conflict between the government and the Houthi movement, which escalated in 2015 when Houthi fighters stormed the presidential palace. After President Hadi was forced to resign an international coalition led by Saudi Arabia and the UAE began bombing Houthi-controlled areas.?

Yemen faces the largest food security emergency in the world with 65,000 people facing IPC Phase 5 (Catastrophe) levels of food insecurity in December 2018 and January 2019. Approximately 5 million people are in IPC Phase 4 (Emergency), and 10.8 million people in IPC Phase 3 (Crisis). 16.4 million people also lack access to adequate healthcare, of which 9.3 million are in acute need. In addition, there have been outbreaks of cholera and diphtheria.?

Widespread violations of international humanitarian law have resulted in loss of life and destruction of infrastructure. Two million people have been internally displaced and an estimated 130,000 have left the country since March 2015. Fighting and airstrikes limit access to humanitarian assistance.?

Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula has an active presence in some of the southern governorates, as does the Yemeni branch of ISIS, although to a much lesser degree.?

For 2019, INFORM rated Yemen's risk of humanitarian crisis very high, at 7.8/10. The "Hazard and exposure" category is ranked at an alarming level of 8.1/10.?
YEM.latest_developments_past:
10/12: At least 63,500 people in Yemen are facing IPC Phase 5 Catastrophe level of food insecurity in December 2018 and January 2019. Overall, 15.9 million Yemenis - 53% of the country's population – are food insecure (IPC Phase 3 Crisis or above), with current levels of humanitarian food assistance.? 

12/11: Civilians and medical staff are at risk amid renewed fighting in Al Hudaydah close to Al Thawra, the city’s main hospital. Airstrikes damaged the 22 May hospital and a pharmacy in Al Hudaydah city.? 

30/10: Access constraints are hindering humanitarian efforts. Active conflict is preventing access to 52,000 tonnes of grains stored near Al Hudaydah. Authorities are blocking imports of humanitarian supplies and winterisation in Aden port and Sana’a airport.?

ZMB.main:
Zambia was affected by prolonged dry spells during the 2017/2018 rainy season leading to a critical drop in crop production and high levels of food insecurity.

Up to 610,000 people will face IPC 3 and 4 between July and September 2018. Eastern, Western, and Southern provinces are most affected. Over 954,000 people are expected to experience IPC 3 and 4 between October 2018 and March 2019. Compared to 77,000 reported as food insecure in 2017, this represents an increase of almost 1150%.

Food insecurity due to natural disasters has often been reported in in Zambia. However this year results are among the highest reported in last five years. The country continues to suffer from chronic undernutrition and poverty. Over 40% of the population is stunted.?

INFORM measures Zambia's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 4.1/10. Lack of coping capacity and vulnerability are of particular concern at 5.8/10 and 5.9/10, respectively. ?
ZMB.latest_developments_past: No significant recent humanitarian developments. This country is being monitored by our analysis team. Last checked 13/11.

ZWE.main: The food security situation in Zimbabwe continues to deteriorate as multiple issues affect food prices, access and availability. At the same time cholera and typhoid outbreaks are creating a severe strain on Zimbabwe’s underfunded health infrastructure.
ZWE.latest_developments_past:
30/11: Commodity prices continue increasing with maize now costing 76% more than the same period in 2017.?

30/11: The ongoing cholera outbreak has spread from Harare to Mashonaland central province, with 181 suspected cases as of 30/11. ?
